sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,Ode II. On Music., in Poetical Essays, (Glasgow, 1788), 153-154.

head.title: Ode II. On Music.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 153-154.

l.emph: Music has charms to sooth a savage beast,
To soften rocks, and bend the knotted oak.

epigraph.bibl: Congreve.22 William Congreve, The Mourning Bride (performed at Lincoln’s Inns Field in 1697 and published in 1703), 1.1.1. Congreve’s line reads “Music has charms to sooth a savage breast” rather than, as Turnbull writes, “a savage beast.”

lg.l: When Orpheus33 Pre-Homeric poet who mesmerized wild beasts through music, aided the Argonauts in resisting the lure of Sirens through song and, in the story of Eurydice, charmed Pluto and Persephone into restoring Eurydice as long as he did not look back when ascending Hades. touch’d the breathing lute,
And mourn’d along the Stygian shore;44 Styx, principal river of the underworld.
Th’ infernal furies then were mute,
And tort’ring fiends their tasks forbore.
Charm’d with the sweetness of the song,
The rugged rocks obey the sound;
The stately oaks together throng,
And dance the mournful Bard around.
So they’d the charms of Music paint,
Which languid words can ne’er express;
The pow’rs of eloquence seem faint,
And all description make them less.
Rous’d by the trumpet’s warlike sound,
To glory ev’ry heart aspires;
The neighing coursers, proudly bound,
And fear from ev’ry breast retires.
But when devotion swells the note,
And through the sacred dome resounds;
All earthly numbers are forgot,
Lost in the sweet seraphic sounds.
Th’ Almighty Sov’reign, thron’d on high,
Delighted hears his praise ascend;
And, as the numbers reach the sky,
Bright crowds of angels list’ning bend.
